Situation1: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: The roster is tight today and the coordinator reminded everyone that each role starts as soon as the doors open.
Story:
I glanced at the clock as I scrubbed the bathroom tiles, sweat beading on my forehead. The smell of bleach clung to my hands, and I could still see dust in the corners of the hallway. As a housekeeping cleaner, I was expected to leave every room spotless, and my supervisor had just reminded me that today’s inspection would be extra strict. I knew I couldn’t rush—every surface needed to shine, every bin emptied, every floor mopped until it gleamed.

But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift started in thirty minutes. The coordinator’s message echoed in my mind, “Please be on time—every minute counts today.” I pictured the people waiting at the shelter, counting on us to open the doors right on schedule. My heart pounded as I weighed the mop in my hand, torn between the demands of my job and my commitment to volunteering. I felt the pressure mounting, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once, and both roles expected nothing less than my full dedication.
